docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that it had stopped marketing and most enrollment in its Medicare plans after a Federal review that criticized the company. The managed-care company, which offers coverage to Medicare patients in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, said the action would let it improve its Medicare operations. Medicare is the Government health program for the elderly.

headline.main: Oxford Health Cuts Back Its Medicare Plans

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc says it has stopped marketing and most enrollment in its Medicare plans after Federal review that criticized company; Oxford says it will use suspension to develop plan to comply with contract requirements of Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which audited company's Medicare operations in February (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years after accounting rule makers shied away from a plan that would have made it more costly to issue stock options, a popular executive perk, they have given preliminary approval to a proposal that could make it harder for companies to sell discounted stock to the rank-and-file. Fewer than 20 percent of all companies have stock purchase programs for their employees, recent estimates suggest. And only about half of those companies have the more generous plans that are growing in popularity but would most likely be shaved back if the proposal is finally approved.

headline.main: New Proposal Would Alter Stock Sales to Employees

docs.abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board gives preliminary approval to proposal that could make it harder for companies to sell discounted stock to rank-and-file; under the plan, companies that give employees more than 15 percent discount on stock would be required to treat discount as an expense, an amount that would come straight off company's bottom line; to avoid new expense, many companies would likely limit discount to 15 percent; proposal is drawing controversy because board, under pressure from corporate executives, backed away from similar proposal in 1994 that would have most likely forced companies to ration number of stock options they hand out, mostly to executives and managers (M)
docs.snippet: Three years after accounting rule makers shied away from a plan that would have made it more costly to issue stock options, a popular executive perk, they have given preliminary approval to a proposal that could make it harder for companies to sell...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted tonight to use part of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices to give an income-tax break to married couples with low and moderate incomes. The vote gave additional strength to anti-smoking legislation that has been before the Senate for three weeks. The marriage-tax amendment was approved on a voice vote, after a procedural motion to kill it failed on a 50-to-48 roll-call along party lines.

headline.main: SENATE BACKS USE OF CIGARETTE TAX TO ASSIST COUPLES

docs.abstract: Senate votes to use part of money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices to give income-tax break to married couples with low and moderate incomes; vote gives additional strength to anti-smoking legislation; marriage-tax amendment is approved on voice vote, after procedural motion to kill it fails on 50-to-48 roll-call along party lines; Republican amendment would give couples with annual incomes below $50,000 new tax deduction of $825 this year, rising gradually to $3,300 in 2008; amendment would also allow self-employed taxpayers to deduct full cost of their medical insurance premiums beginning with this year's taxes (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate voted tonight to use part of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices to give an income-tax break to married couples with low and moderate incomes. The vote gave additional strength to anti-smoking legislation that has...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Pharmacists who provide personal service on prescriptions are indeed being squeezed by managed care (news article, June 4). The paradox is that in most states, pharmacy-practice laws and regulations require pharmacists to counsel patients about their prescription medications. Many studies have shown that pharmacist counseling and intervention can reduce adverse drug reactions, improve therapeutic outcomes and reduce health care costs.
docs.abstract: Pharmacy school Dean Stephen M Gross letter on June 4 article agrees pharmacists who provide personal service on prescriptions are being squeezed by managed care; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I agree with Dr. Susan Love (Op-Ed, June 7) that medical costs skyrocketed because third-party payers created incentives to overdiagnose and overtreat. So long as someone else pays medical bills, costs will rise.

docs.lead_paragraph: The visit this week of an 85-year-old doctor from Italy who claims to have successfully treated thousands of cancer patients with a cocktail of vitamins and hormones has set off a debate within Canada's universal health care system about patients' rights and alternative treatments. The arrival of the Italian, Dr. Luigi Di Bella, on Sunday for a week of meetings and appearances was reported on the front pages of Toronto's daily newspapers and on television news reports. Enthusiastic supporters have cheered him as he met with Canada's top doctors in hopes of convincing them that his treatment should be approved in Canada.

headline.main: A Cocktail of Chemicals to Treat Cancer Has Canada in a Stir

docs.abstract: Arrival in Canada of Luigi Di Bella, Italian doctor who claims to have sucessfully treated thousands of cancer patients with cocktail of vitamins and hormones, has set off debate within Canada's universal health care system about patients' rights and alternative treatments; Di Bella is in Canada for week of meetings and appearances (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Susan Love (Op-Ed, June 7) has an overly optimistic faith in the ability of regulation to correct the deficiencies of managed care. But any system that restricts care for economic gain has as many problems as a system that encourages profligate spending on unnecessary tests and procedures. Profits siphon funds from patients into the pockets of stockholders.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert M Kaiser letter on Dr Susan Love's June 7 article holds Love is unrealistic about ability of regulation to correct deficiences of managed health care; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 New Leader in Nigeria Promises Elections Nigeria's new military leader said he would turn over power to an elected civilian Government by Oct. 1. It was not clear whether the new leadership would allow genuine opposition candidates to run. Aides to the new head of state also hinted that they were preparing to release of some of the country's many political prisoners, as a gesture of goodwill. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: JOE PEREZ'S pulse quickens when the phone rings inside his storefront office at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps. The adrenaline rush psyches him up to respond to a cardiac call or some other code-red emergency. It also fuels his response to the corps's lingering code green, a lack of funds that has left these trailblazers having to perform triage on their bills. ''We're going belly up,'' Mr. Perez said. ''Every other call is someone calling for money. Our copy machine, they want to take it out of here. Everybody is suing us.''

headline.main: About New York; Cash Squeeze Makes It Hard To Save Lives

docs.abstract: About New York column on financial straits of Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps, which in ten years has cut Brooklyn area's ambulance response time from half an hour to minutes; founders Joe Perez and Rocky Robinson comment (S)
